title: Does Being a Woman Predispose You to Wet AMD?
author: Stefani Kim

content: Women may have a higher risk of developing wet AMD, and that risk may be related to hormones. Hormone replacement therapy may moderate that risk, according to research, suggesting that the female endocrine system could play a role in the onset of AMD.

Women are more prone to hormone imbalance disorders than men, and those imbalances can contribute to the development of other diseases. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), an eye disease that causes retinal damage and potential vision loss, might be one of them.

Estrogen could influence the development of advanced or wet AMD, a more serious form of the disease where abnormal blood vessel growth leads to sudden vision loss, according to research published in JAMA Ophthalmology . Postmenopausal women in the study who used hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in addition to oral contraceptives containing estrogen were less likely to develop wet AMD. However, no benefit was seen for early AMD.

Women’s tendency to live longer than men may already predispose them to AMD, as age is a well-established risk factor for the disease, according to  Christina Weng, MD, a retinal specialist, surgeon, and professor at the Baylor College of Medicine. But other factors may come into play as well.

content: “There are some studies that, even accounting for that discrepancy in lifespan, they’ve still seen a persistent effect based on sex,” said Weng. Some of the potential influences include higher estrogen levels, vascular factors, genetics, and inflammation. “Some women are more prone to autoimmune diseases and rheumatologic diseases, so we know that there are different inflammatory factors.”

Both wet AMD and the geographic atrophy in dry AMD are linked to inflammation . Menopausal women have an increased risk of inflammation as estrogen levels decrease, suggesting a potential link to the eye disease.

“Based on laboratory and clinical research, we know that estrogen can confer certain effects on other ocular diseases like cataracts , but in AMD the data really is pretty inconclusive,” said Weng. “At this point, I leave decisions with regards to HRT to the patient and their primary care doctor or OB/GYN.”

The research connecting gender as a standalone factor for AMD is still in its early stages, and more evidence is needed. Both men and women should get their annual dilated eye exam to screen for a variety of eye-related diseases, said Weng.

content: Other clinicians, like Vaidehi Dedania, MD, a retinal ophthalmologist and surgeon at NYU Langone Health, are similarly skeptical about the connection between AMD and gender, given the science.
“I would say it’s inconclusive,” said Dedania. “A lot of the studies are usually reports.”
